content: Meeting in 5 minutes.
As a reminder, one of the things I'd like to discuss today is statistics/metrics we can track (or at least questions we'd like to answer) with regards to rust-lang/rust's PR queue.
@T-release meeting!
(as an fyi, I have a hard stop today)
@DPC appears to not be around today, so we'll skip the wg-triage checkin I guess
ok, let's open the statistics/metrics discussion - I came up with a few of my own, let's maybe try to assemble a list first and then we can dive in on some of them (or just leave it at that, maybe)?

• What is the distribution for a PRs latency to merge, from opening?
  • how long does a PR spend in assignment to X (regardless of whether approved by X)? (Roughly a stat per reviewer)
  • do PRs get stuck waiting for reviewer, or do PRs just need many rounds of review and are getting updated frequently?
Anyone else assemble lists or so?

• How many PRs are closed while waiting on review?
  • How many PRs are closed-inactive?
  • Of the PRs closed-inactive, how long has it been since the last activity? Since the PR was opened?
let's try this: @triagebot end-topic (just on whether we're done generating a list, not discussing this)

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

Those all seem good to me. There is a question of presentation about 2 in @simulacrum‚Äôs list, specifically I wouldn‚Äôt want that stat to become a ‚Äúshame list‚Äù of people who don‚Äôt review in a timely manner.
it would also be interesting to compare review latency to number of PRs assigned

XAMPPRocky said:

Those all seem good to me. There is a question of presentation about 2 in simulacrum‚Äôs list, specifically I wouldn‚Äôt want that stat to become a ‚Äúshame list‚Äù of people who don‚Äôt review in a timely manner.

Yes, for sure, though I do think having that data may mean that we can use it to have much more productive conversations and potentially even triage - it might be nice for authors of PRs to know there's silence because their reviewer usually does batches every 2 weeks for example, or something like that.
Yep definitely, I do think that data would be valuable, just not sure how to present it.

I think it would be quite fine for any sort of per-reviewer data to be kept largely private (though of course maybe the script to generate it is public); I would not expect a dashboard or ranking of any kind.
yeah I think having the data be private is fine -- I would also keep the script private if possible, to avoid people just generating the dashboard for themselves
ok, so it sounds like we have a good set of questions -- other than @XAMPPRocky's good point, any other notes?
(to show it we can use the new shiny private github pages I guess)
@Pietro Albini Oh true! I‚Äôve been using that at work, and it works really well.
yeah, I'm less worried about that. One question I have - would anyone here be interested in writing that script or whatever we use, to start trying to answer these?
I'm thinking it'd be nice to have it roughly in 2-3 weeks, or at least, some idea of what we might need to collect over time (if there's not an easy way to look back into history)
I could try and work on it over that time.
Sounds great!
We'll probably check in on it in 2 weeks, as next week we'll have release retro.
At the very least, it‚Äôs an excuse to improve Octocrab‚Äôs support üòÑ
ok, I think that's all from me - @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok, the next thing is the release - shipping next week
PR for version bump is up and approved
I should have time to do release stuff, but can I fall back onto you for specific tasks if I suddently get busy @simulacrum?

@Pietro Albini have you had a chance to check in? I know @Eric Huss volunteered to do a beta backport rollup, and I believe @pnkfelix is going to try to wrestle bors today to try and get one or two PRs over the edge too

Pietro Albini said:

I should have time to do release stuff, but can I fall back onto you for specific tasks if I suddently get busy simulacrum?

Yeah, though given why you might get busy I might also be :)
:sweat_smile:.
ok - I think we're on track
@XAMPPRocky once Pietro's PR bumping the version number lands in theory you could start working on release notes for 1.51, but of course no pressure
Yeah I plan to start on it next week.
Great!
The blog post also looks pretty good - I left some comment on wednesday I think, @cuviper do you think you'll have the time to take a look and polish it according to the feedback?
I will try to do that this weekend. I think there were a couple suggested paragraphs to add on array init and slice fill
Then we can pare it back, I guess
Yeah, potentially replacing some of the existing ones
Sounds good to me.
Ok, @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
Okay, sounds like that's all. Thanks everyone.
